t: Job 11
Zophar Rebukes Job
Then*p Zophar the Naamathite answered,
“Shall*pn a multitude of words go unanswered, And*ln a talkative man be acquitted?
Shall*ln your boasts silence men? And*ln shall you scoff and none rebuke?
For*ln you have said, ‘My teaching is pure, And*ln I am innocent in your eyes.’
But*ln would that God might speak, And*ln open His lips against you,
And*ln show you the secrets of wisdom! For*ln sound wisdom has two sides. Know*ln then that God forgets a part of your iniquity.
“Can*ln you discover the depths of God? Can*ln you discover the limits of the Almighty?
They*iln are*i high as the heavens, what can you do? Deeper*ln than Sheol, what can you know?
Its*ln measure is longer than the earth And*ln broader than the sea.
If*ln He passes by or shuts up, Or*ln calls an assembly, who can restrain Him?
For*ln He knows false men, And*ln He sees iniquity without investigating.
An*ln idiot will become intelligent When*ln the foal of a wild donkey is born a man.
“If*ln you would direct your heart right And*ln spread out your hand to Him,
If*ln iniquity is in your hand, put it far away, And*ln do not let wickedness dwell in your tents;
Then,*ln indeed, you could lift up your face without moral*i defect, And*ln you would be steadfast and not fear.
For*ln you would forget your*i trouble, As*ln waters that have passed by, you would remember it.*i
Your*ln life would be brighter than noonday; Darkness*ln would be like the morning.
Then*ln you would trust, because there is hope; And*ln you would look around and rest securely.
You*ln would lie down and none would disturb you,*i And*ln many would entreat your favor.
But*ln the eyes of the wicked will fail, And*ln there will be no escape for them; And*ln their hope is to breathe their last.”
